page.title: 15LOPWELL DAM BY BERE FERRERS
page.content: The way to Lopwell Dam,just a little N.E. of Bere Ferrers,leads through woods where there are remains of silver mining.This was at its height first in Edward I's reign when growth and prosperity was brought to the area-"the most highly organised mining community in Southern England for 200 years".Ore was smelted in the Tavy Valley later. Electricity comes from the CEGB which crosses both the Tamar and Tavy on pylons.This is supplemented by electricity produced at Lopwell Dam- 11,000 watts in all.The Dam is 300ft long and 10ft high.It is made of rubble rock faced with granite and concrete blocks.Water is drawn off through a 27" concrete pipe which is 120yds downstream.There is a new pumping station carefully covered over to avoid spoiling fine riverside views
